channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: At Campaign Stop, Netanyahu Admits Jerusalem Settlement Was Strategic
item.description: The Israeli leader’s visit to Har Homa gave him a chance to appeal to pro-settlement voters and to rebut criticism about his handling of a housing crisis.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited the Jerusalem neighborhood of Har Homa during a campaign stop on Monday, one day before the general election.

item.title: Daughter of Jailed Malaysian Opposition Leader Is Arrested
item.description: Nurul Izzah Anwar, a daughter of Anwar Ibrahim, was arrested over criticism of the country’s judiciary she made during a speech in Parliament, her lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Nurul Izzah Anwar at a rally this month in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Unveils Plan to Bolster Its National Soccer Team
item.description: The men’s national team has never lived up to the expectation of Chinese fans. Now the government is pushing for changes that it hopes will bring better results
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Students at a competition at the University of South China in Hengyang, Hunan Province, in June.

item.title: As British Election Nears, Cameron Promises Another Dose of Austerity
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron has made cutting the budget a signature of his platform, but compared with much of Europe, the cuts are modest.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain addressing the British Chambers of Commerce in February. Mr. Cameron has promised to further reduce government spending.

item.title: Vladimir Putin Returns After Absence and Dismisses Rumors
item.description: The Russian leader reappeared in public after more than 10 days, appearing healthy and commenting wryly that things “would be boring without rumors.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin met with the president of Kyrgyzstan, Almazbek Atambayev, in St. Petersburg on Monday.

item.title: ISIS Maintains Hold in Tikrit as Iraq Pauses Offensive
item.description: Officials said they were slowing the operation to call for reinforcements and to preserve property and civilian lives.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Government soldiers in Tikrit, Iraq, on Sunday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Becomes World’s Third-Largest Arms Exporter
item.description: With 5 percent of total arms exports, China surpassed Germany in the rankings, but the U.S. and Russia remain the top sellers of weapons worldwide, a research organization said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The J-31 fighter, which China hopes to export as a lower-cost stealth aircraft, was prominently displayed at Airshow China in November.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Greek Debt Crisis’ Great Divide
item.description: Greece is trapped between creditors who don’t trust it and hard-line Syriza members who insist on rolling back earlier measures — even at the cost of exiting the eurozone.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: The Kurds’ Heroic Stand Against ISIS
item.description: The Kurds, a stateless people, have held the front against ISIS in Iraq. Is America helping them?
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT ATRAN and DOUGLAS M. STONE

item.title: Letter Calls Plea Deal for David Petraeus a ‘Profound Double Standard’
item.description: A lawyer for an imprisoned government contractor who revealed classified information has criticized the plea deal given to retired Gen. David H. Petraeus, who gave military secrets to his mistress.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: A plea deal given to retired Gen. David H. Petraeus allows for no jail time for sharing classified information with his biographer and lover.

item.title: Chinese Ex-General, Charged With Corruption, Dies
item.description: Xu Caihou became one of the highest-ranking targets of President Xi Jinping’s antigraft campaign after the party announced the investigation into him last June.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: General Xu Caihou was a vice chairman of the Communist Party’s Central Military Commission, which oversees the armed forces.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: David Shambaugh on the Risks to Chinese Communist Rule
item.description: The highly influential American scholar of Chinese politics argues that his recent essay about the ‘‘endgame’’ of the Communist Party envisions a protracted period of decline.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Rare Look Into One’s Life on File in China
item.description: There is a largely invisible mechanism of social control that governs hundreds of millions of urban residents in China: the dang’an, or personal file, that documents matters mundane and profane.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: The Tibetan writer Tsering Woeser is among the few Chinese citizens who has peered inside her dang'an, or personal file.

item.title: Egypt’s Leader Showcases Plans for Growth
item.description: A conference meant to showcase President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s economic reforms also included signs of his government’s continued dependence on the monarchies that aided his rise to power.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS

item.title: Leading Role for France as Africa Battles Back
item.description: France has joined an increasingly violent campaign to combat Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa and other Islamist extremists, and more recently to thwart Boko Haram.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A French soldier in January at a new forward-operating base in Madama, in northern Niger, 60 miles from the Libyan border.

item.title: Jaffna Journal: Sri Lanka’s Tamil Minority Grows Impatient With Just Promises
item.description: Wounds of Sri Lanka’s decades-long civil war that ended in 2009 are still widely apparent, and the Tamil minority is growing impatient with a recently elected government that vowed to hasten the postwar reconciliation process.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kannaki Camp in central Jaffna has housed displaced Tamil people since the Sri Lankan military seized their land.

item.title: Kerry Suggests There Is a Place for Assad in Syria Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said that he still believed it was important to achieve a diplomatic solution for the conflict in Syria and that the negotiations should involve President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Flights Over Vanuatu Are Expected to Reveal Cyclone Devastation
item.description: Aid workers on the ground said the tiny nation’s capital had been flattened after the powerful storm tore through the archipelago.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: The remains of homes damaged by Cyclone Pam outside the Vanuatu capital, Port-Vila, on Sunday.

item.title: Putin Says He Weighed Nuclear Alert Over Crimea
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said in a documentary that he weighed putting Russia’s nuclear arsenal on alert because of his concerns about anarchy and Western intervention over Crimea.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: The documentary "Homeward Bound" was produced by the state-run Rossiya 1 channel to celebrate the anniversary of the March 21, 2014, annexation of Crimea.

item.title: Despite Good Intentions, Vacancies in Refugee Camp in Jordan for Syrians
item.description: The shortfall in the number of refugees is symbolic of a wider breakdown in the system to save Syrians from a civil war that is entering its fifth year.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unoccupied shelters at Al Azraq refugee camp in Jordan.
